explanation:
For determining whether any pointer in OS_TaskGetInfo should be const-qualified, the next analyst needs the exact types, macros and prototypes that determine what is read vs written and what types the expressions have:

- OS_task_prop_t
  - Required to know the types and mutability of members (e.g. name[], creator, stack_size, priority). The function writes into *task_prop (memset, strncpy, assignments) so this shows which members must be non-const and whether any members are inherently const-qualified.

- OS_common_record_t
  - Provides the declaration of record and its members (notably name_entry and creator). If record is only read, it could be a pointer-to-const; the definition is needed to decide whether record can/should have been declared const OS_common_record_t *.

- OS_task_internal_record_t
  - Provides the declaration of task and its members (stack_size, priority). The function only reads these fields, so the type definition is needed to decide if task should be const-qualified.

- OS_object_token_t
  - The token type is passed to OS_ObjectIdGetById (output) and OS_TaskGetInfo_Impl and OS_ObjectIdRelease. Its definition/prototype is needed to see whether token is mutable and if any pointers to it should be const.

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET (macro)
  - This macro produces the expression assigned to record and task. Its expansion determines the exact pointer type returned (pointer-to-const or pointer-to-non-const) and whether assigning to a const-qualified local pointer would be compatible.

- OS_CHECK_POINTER (macro)
  - The macro may impose requirements on task_prop (for example by casting or taking its address) or expand to behavior that affects whether task_prop may be const; its definition is needed to ensure adding const wouldn't break the check.

- OS_ObjectIdGetById (prototype/semantics)
  - Needed to know which parameters are inputs/outputs (in particular the token out-parameter) and whether any const qualification is required or prevented by its signature.

- OS_TaskGetInfo_Impl (prototype)
  - The function is called with &token and task_prop; its parameter types must be known to know whether task_prop (or token) must be non-const because the implementation may write through those pointers.

- OS_ObjectIdRelease (prototype)
  - Called with &token; its prototype/semantics confirm whether token must be mutable and thus whether token's type can be const-qualified.

- OS_global_task_table and OS_task_table (declarations/types)
  - The table object types and their element types determine the return type of OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and whether the returned pointers refer to modifiable storage; this affects if record and task can be const pointers.

In summary: to judge whether any of the local pointer variables (record, task, token, or the task_prop parameter) could or should be const-qualified, the exact type definitions and macro/function signatures listed above are required so the analyzer can determine which memory is actually written to and what signatures force non-const parameters.
